result.value: https://github.com/gversmee/dbgap2x

result.original_header: dbGaP returns the list of the studies related to your term. As you see, there are 6 studies associated with the "Jackson Heart Study" (JHS). One of these study is the main one a.k.a the "parent study", whereas the other ones are substudies. In this case, phs000286.v5.p1 is the parent study. Firslty, we can use the phs.version() function in order to be sure that this is the latest version of the study. We can abbreviate the phs name by giving just the digit, or we can use the full dbGaP id.
parent_header: Using dbgap2x, R package to explore, download and decrypt phenotypic and genomic data from dbGaP
Search for dbGaP studies
Let's try to explore the "Jackson Heart Study" cohort that exists on dbGaP.

result.original_header: Using dbgap2x, R package to explore, download and decrypt phenotypic and genomic data from dbGaP
result.value:
You can test this software:
- Using the dockerized version on your local device by running


```bash
docker run -p 80:8888 -v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock  gversmee/dbgap2x
```

and then open your web browser at http://localhost, and use the password `dbgap2x`
- Using your local R by installing the package with


```R
install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("gversmee/dbgap2x")
```

For using the package with a fresh R installation, make sure your system has the following libraries: libcurl4-openssl-dev libssl-dev libxml2-dev.
Example for a debian system:

```bash
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install libcurl4-openssl-dev libssl-dev libxml2-dev -y
```

result.original_header: Load the package
parent_header: Using dbgap2x, R package to explore, download and decrypt phenotypic and genomic data from dbGaP
Introduction
result.value:
```R
#devtools::install_github("gversmee/dbgap2x", force = TRUE)
library(dbgap2x)
```

result.original_header: Decrypt the .ncbi_enc files
parent_header: Using dbgap2x, R package to explore, download and decrypt phenotypic and genomic data from dbGaP
Extract your study
result.value:
On dbGaP, the phenotypic files are encrypted. We created a decryption function that uses a dockerized version on sratoolkit. To use that function, you need to have docker installed on your device (www.docker.com). If you are using the dockerized version of this software (available at hub.docker.com/r/gversmee/dbgap2x), docker is already pre-installed, but you'll need to upload your key on the jupyter working directory.


```R
key <- "path/to/your/key.ngc"
files <- "path/to/directory/ofencrypted_files"
dbgap.decrypt(files, key)
```

You should see a "decrypted_files" directory in the directory where your encrypted files are located

result.original_header: - Click on "file selector"
parent_header: Using dbgap2x, R package to explore, download and decrypt phenotypic and genomic data from dbGaP
Extract your study
Download dbGaP files
result.value: This gives you access to the dbGaP file selector where you can find all the files available for the selected project. To find it, go to the `Authorized Access` and then `My Projects` tabs. Then, in the column `Actions` on the right of your screen, find `file selector`.

result.original_header: - Filter again
parent_header: Using dbgap2x, R package to explore, download and decrypt phenotypic and genomic data from dbGaP
Extract your study
Download dbGaP files
result.value: Since we are only interested in getting the phenotypic data, let's filter by `Content type` and select `phenotype individual-auxiliary` and `phenotype individual-traits`.

result.original_header: - Select the files
parent_header: Using dbgap2x, R package to explore, download and decrypt phenotypic and genomic data from dbGaP
Extract your study
Download dbGaP files
result.value: Click on "+" to select all the files.

result.original_header: - Click on "Cart file"
parent_header: Using dbgap2x, R package to explore, download and decrypt phenotypic and genomic data from dbGaP
Extract your study
Download dbGaP files
result.value: This will downlaod a .krt file in your download folder.

result.original_header: Download and decrypt the files
parent_header: Using dbgap2x, R package to explore, download and decrypt phenotypic and genomic data from dbGaP
Extract your study
result.value:
```R
key <- "path/to/your/key.ngc"
cart <- "path/to/your/cartfile.krt"
dbgap.download(cart, key)
```

You should see in your working directory a new folder named dbGaP-*** that contains your files

Search for dbGaP studies
Let's try to explore the "Jackson Heart Study" cohort that exists on dbGaP.

result.original_header: dbGaP returns the list of the studies related to your term. As you see, there are 6 studies associated with the "Jackson Heart Study" (JHS). One of these study is the main one a.k.a the "parent study", whereas the other ones are substudies. In this case, phs000286.v5.p1 is the parent study. Firslty, we can use the phs.version() function in order to be sure that this is the latest version of the study. We can abbreviate the phs name by giving just the digit, or we can use the full dbGaP id.

Search for dbGaP studies

result.original_header: The is.parent() function is usefull to test if a study is a parent study or a substudy
parent_header: Using dbgap2x, R package to explore, download and decrypt phenotypic and genomic data from dbGaP
Search for dbGaP studies
Let's try to explore the "Jackson Heart Study" cohort that exists on dbGaP.
result.value:
```R
is.parent("000286") # JHS main cohort
is.parent("phs499") # substudy "CARe" for JHS
```


TRUE



FALSE

Search for dbGaP studies

```R
browse.dbgap("286", no.browser = TRUE)

```


'https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/projects/gap/cgi-bin/study.cgi?study_id=phs000286.v6.p2'



'https://www.jacksonheartstudy.org'

result.original_header: For each dbGaP study, there can be multiple consent groups that will have there specificities. Use consent.groups to know the number and the name of the consent groups in the study that you are exploring. Let's keep focusing on JHS.

Explore the characteristics of your study
result.value:
```R JHS <- "phs000286" consent.groups(JHS) ```
shortNamelongName
0NRUP Subjects did not participate in the study, did not complete a consent document and are included only for the pedigree structure and/or genotype controls, such as HapMap subjects
1HMB-IRB-NPU Health/Medical/Biomedical (IRB, NPU)
2DS-FDO-IRB-NPU Disease-Specific (Focused Disease Only, IRB, NPU)
3HMB-IRB Health/Medical/Biomedical (IRB)
4DS-FDO-IRB Disease-Specific (Focused Disease Only, IRB)

On dbGaP, the phenotypic files are encrypted. We created a decryption function that uses a dockerized version on sratoolkit. To use that function, you need to have docker installed on your device (www.docker.com). If you are using the dockerized version of this software (available at hub.docker.com/r/gversmee/dbgap2x), docker is already pre-installed, but you'll need to upload your key on the jupyter working directory.

result.original_header: dbGaP returns the list of the studies related to your term. As you see, there are 6 studies associated with the "Jackson Heart Study" (JHS). One of these study is the main one a.k.a the "parent study", whereas the other ones are substudies. In this case, phs000286.v5.p1 is the parent study. Firslty, we can use the phs.version() function in order to be sure that this is the latest version of the study. We can abbreviate the phs name by giving just the digit, or we can use the full dbGaP id.
parent_header: Using dbgap2x, R package to explore, download and decrypt phenotypic and genomic data from dbGaP
Search for dbGaP studies
Let's try to explore the "Jackson Heart Study" cohort that exists on dbGaP.

result.original_header: For each dbGaP study, there can be multiple consent groups that will have there specificities. Use consent.groups to know the number and the name of the consent groups in the study that you are exploring. Let's keep focusing on JHS.

result.original_header: Get your dbGaP repository key
parent_header: Using dbgap2x, R package to explore, download and decrypt phenotypic and genomic data from dbGaP
Extract your study
result.value: In order to download or decrypt your data from dbGaP, you will need to request an access and to get a decryption key. Follow those steps to access your dbGaP repository key:

result.original_header: - Get a PI dbGaP repository key:
parent_header: Using dbgap2x, R package to explore, download and decrypt phenotypic and genomic data from dbGaP
Extract your study
Get your dbGaP repository key
result.value: In order to download the files and to decrypt them, you will need a decryption key. This key can be found on a PI dbGaP account. Go to the `Authorized Access` and then `My Projects` tabs. Then, in the column `Actions` on the right of your screen, find `Get no password dbGaP repository key`.
